pullRequest.title: Im 20200316 lastn operation elasticsearch
pullRequest.bodyText: Working implementation of $lastn operation that uses Elasticsearch v6 for indexing observations.

nodes.bodyText: Is the embedded elasticsearch actually exposing itself on the port on the whole system? It looks like it is, I'm wondering if there are any security implications to not securing it, or are we leaving it up to implementers to make sure they don't expose the port publicly?
Would love to see a javadoc here if possible!
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,34 @@
+package ca.uhn.fhir.jpa.api.dao;
+
+import ca.uhn.fhir.jpa.searchparam.SearchParameterMap;

nodes.bodyText: Running into intermittents? Was this intended to be added? this just ensures non-parallel IT yeah?

nodes.bodyText: What happens when the user submits other sort orders in the query? Looks here like we silently drop them, I imagine this is the correct

2 things:

Is it worth checking if this is not size 1?
This whole arrow code section can be replaced with a stream i think

String subjectId = subjectReferenceElement.stream()
.map(refElement -> mySearchParameterExtractor.extractReferenceLinkFromResource(refElement, "Observation.subject"))
.map(sPathAndRef -> sPathAndRef.getRef())
.map(subjectRef -> subjectRef.getReferenceElement().getValue())
.findFirst().orElse(null);
Probably gotta throw some filter(Objects::nonNull) in there too. This may make it easier to read if you're partial to streams
Just to be clear, it is out of scope to get the Last 3 blood pressure observations that came into the system, regardless of who they are for ?
This function is quite long, and could probably do with having the last half of it split into a helper function called createOrUpdateIndexedObservation which handles that chunk
This function seems like a good candidate to return an Optional
perhaps findBy is a better prefix, as that is what spring-data seems to use by default
Too many spaces between IbasePersistedResource and theEntity

Seems like you may be able to extract at least part of this to the superclass, or is there something R4-specific happening here outside of IndexObservation, which could probably just as easily take an IAnyResource
I feel as though this operation isn't idempotent, or is this some other meaning of idempotent I'm not getting?
I'm not sure what our policy is on huge JSON strings in code, wondering if this would be better extracted into a resource. I may be wrong here, feel free to ignore this comment
Out of curiosity why do we need norms here? Are we scoring on length of field?
Are we doing fuzzy matching on the text fields, or exact matching? If only the latter, keyword-matching is wayyy faster.

Would like to know the rationale for store:true here, as it seems these are pretty compact objects and this would take up extra space, and provide no value unless you're querying specifically for large swathes of these identifier fields.
move to class level
Are we ever anticipating more than 1 subject? I was under the impression there was only 1 allowed.
Are these todos still relevant? If so, maybe open an issue for them
Would appreciate Javadocs here too
it is unclear how setting IsTest sets chunk size to 50`
I'm confused as to why the pidlist would be padded with -1, am I missing some internal functionality?
suggestion: remove commented code if its unused.
remove this as well
Can you explain the purpose of these embeddable entities to me? I'm unfamiliar with the concept and would like to understand what's going on here a bit better
Am I crazy or are there two CodeSystemHash classes? Any reason for the duplication between jpaserver-model and jpaserver-base?

This function could do with some tidying up, its looking a little hairy. theContext.getVersion().getVersion() can be ripped out into a variable, and each of these 4-level || checks could be broken out so this reads better, e.g.
if (isR5(version) && isLastNParamR5(theParamName))

So in all these cases, SP_PATIENT resolves to "patient" right? I wonder if its worth just returning the string if we detect that the version is legal. Bit of a hack but this seems like a ton of conditionals for what is essentially just:
return "patient" if version >=3 else throw
